Page.Name: Team Lead
Page.Tab_1: <U>Unit Deployment Manager:</U> Major Marks, you're being deployed as the BE Team Lead on the PAM team to an undisclosed bare base location to establish a co-located operating base that will contain Army, Air Force, and British military personnel. You'll be leaving tomorrow at 0800.
Page.instruction: Click the highlighted selection point to access the assessment.

Page.Name: Team Member
Page.Tab_1: <U>Major Marks:</U> We’re being deployed as the PAM team to an undisclosed bare base location to establish a co-located operating base that will contain Army, Air Force, and British Military personnel. We’ll be leaving tomorrow at 0800.
Page.instruction: Click the highlighted selection point to access the assessment.

Page.TranscriptText:
Narrator: Your PAM team is about to land at Woodruff Air Force Base at an undisclosed location in Central Asia where they will serve as the initial medical unit on the ground. It is currently 93 degrees Fahrenheit.

Third Country Nationals (TCNs) are building tent city in accordance with the Expeditionary Site Plan (ESP). The base will be supporting EC-130s and AWACS aircraft.

Page.instruction: Select each graphic to learn more about your team.

Page.TranscriptText: <U>British Counterpart, Squadron Leader Fletcher:</U> Welcome to Woodruff. I'm Squadron Leader Fletcher. We currently have the sleeping area established in the main hangar while the TCNs are building tent city. Would you like to see the hangar first or start with a tour of the installation?
Page.instruction: Make your decision.

Page.CompentancyDescription: Apply preventive medicine aspects to selection of a bed down location.
Page.CompentancyTopic: Basic Site Assessment and Risk Communication Requirements
Page.STS_Line:
• 4.1.2.1 Site Selection
  • 4.1.2.4 Exposure pathway evaluation
Page.Training_Reference:
• AFCENT Deployed BE Guide
  • AFMAN 48-155, Occupational and Environmental Health Exposure Controls
  • AIHA, The Occupational Environment: Its Evaluation, Control and Management
  • ASTM E 2318-03, Standard Guide for Environmental Health Site Assessment Process for Military Deployments
Page.instruction:
Select the appropriate areas,
then click Done.

Page.Tab_1: <U>British Counterpart, Squadron Leader Fletcher:</U> We have 1 Harvest Falcon Latrine and we've been using field showers since we've arrived.
Page.Tab_2: <U>British Counterpart, Squadron Leader Fletcher:</U> All personnel are using bottled water. Each unit has a 3-day supply of water remaining.
Page.Tab_3: <U>British Counterpart, Squadron Leader Fletcher:</U> Yes, we can order additional supplies through the logistics contractor.
Page.Tab_4: <U>British Counterpart, Squadron Leader Fletcher:</U> My unit can continue to prepare food for the next week until things settle down. We've been on base conducting a coalition exercise for the past two weeks.
Page.instruction: Select each question for more information, then click Continue.

Page.Name: Team Lead
Page.TranscriptText:
British Counterpart, Squadron Leader Fletcher: You'll see as we drive along the flight line here that the hangar space is off to your right. Across the main road is where we're establishing tent city.

Those buildings over there along the flight line were probably used by the Russians that occupied this installation during the Cold War.

BE Team Lead, Maj Marks: What do you know about how they used the buildings?

British Counterpart, Squadron Leader Fletcher: We have no idea what they disposed of or used on this base.

BE Team Lead, Maj Marks: What do you know about the threats in the area?

British Counterpart, Squadron Leader Fletcher: After the kidnapping of British Navy personnel and continued support for local insurgents, Country X presents the greatest threat to regional stability. They hold quarterly military exercises which could be ploys for attacks. They also provide cross-border weapons and training to local insurgents. There are few local threats, however Country X and transnational terrorists continue to exhibit hostile intent. Last week a hard-drive was exploited indicating plans to inject KCN into a water system in theater. There was a water system on this base, but it is not operable. Arrangements have been made with the host nation to utilize their existing water sources.

Page.Name: Team Member
Page.TranscriptText:
British Counterpart, Squadron Leader Fletcher: You'll see as we drive along the flight line here that the hangar space is off to your right. Across the main road is where we're establishing tent city.

Those buildings over there along the flight line were probably used by the Russians that occupied this installation during the Cold War.

BE Team Member, TSgt Hopper: What do you know about how they used the buildings?

British Counterpart, Squadron Leader Fletcher: We have no idea what they disposed of or used on this base.

BE Team Member, TSgt Hopper: What do you know about the threats in the area?

British Counterpart, Squadron Leader Fletcher: After the kidnapping of British Navy personnel and continued support for local insurgents, Country X presents the greatest threat to regional stability. They hold quarterly military exercises which could be ploys for attacks. They also provide cross-border weapons and training to local insurgents. There are few local threats, however Country X and transnational terrorists continue to exhibit hostile intent. Last week a hard-drive was exploited indicating plans to inject KCN into a water system in theater. There was a water system on this base, but it is not operable. Arrangements have been made with the host nation to utilize their existing water sources.

Page.Name: Team Lead
Page.TranscriptText:
Control Center (on radio): Control Center to the Squadron Leader. The Commander is establishing a threat working group and requests that the BE Lead report to the building immediately West of the main hangar.

British Counterpart, Squadron Leader Fletcher (on radio): Copy. I'll bring him over.

British Counterpart, Squadron Leader Fletcher (not on radio): Sounds like it's time for you to meet with Colonel Potts.

Page.Name: Team Member
Page.TranscriptText:
Control Center (on radio): Control Center to the Squadron Leader. The Commander is establishing a threat working group and requests that the BE Team report to the building immediately West of the main hangar.

British Counterpart, Squadron Leader Fletcher (on radio): Copy.

British Counterpart, Squadron Leader Fletcher (not on radio): Sounds like it's time for you to meet with Colonel Potts.

Page.Tab_1: <U>Base Commander, Col Potts:</U> We're at force protection Bravo now. I'd like some input from you on whether that's appropriate. Based on your tour, what is your recommendation?
Page.instruction: Click the Commander to hear the question, then select the correct answer.
Select all that apply, then click Done.

Page.Tab_1: <U>Col Potts:</U> Which two measures would you recommend that the CE Commander institute to handle the overflowing latrine?
Page.instruction: Click the Commander to hear the question, then select all that apply.

Page.TranscriptText: <U>Narrator:</U> After traveling for 24 hours, you have not had enough sleep and decide to retire to the cots so that you can get an early start the next morning in daylight.

Page.Name: Team Lead
Page.TranscriptText: <U>Narrator:</U> Upon waking up, you've found your pallets unloaded from the aircraft. Maj Ramirez has found a building of opportunity to use for a clinic. MSgt Dower will help unpack medical supplies from the CONEX. Capt Hall and MSgt Phillips are going to meet with the Commander regarding food and latrine issues. To make the most progress, decide how to task yourself and the remaining team members.
Page.instruction: Drag the items to the appropriate locations, then click Done.

Page.Name: Team Member
Page.TranscriptText: <U>Narrator:</U> Upon waking up, you've found your pallets unloaded from the aircraft. Maj Ramirez has found a building of opportunity to use for a clinic. MSgt Dower will help unpack medical supplies from the CONEX. Capt Hall and MSgt Phillips are going to meet with the Commander regarding food and latrine issues. To make the most progress, decide how Maj Marks should task himself and the remaining team members.
Page.instruction: Drag the items to the appropriate locations, then click Done.

Page.Name: Team Lead
Page.TranscriptText:
Narrator: While you could split your team several different ways to accomplish these tasks based on team member strengths, for the purposes of this response you will proceed with assessment of the area where tent city is being constructed; the two BE NCOs, TSgt Hopper and SSgt Johnson, will work on identifying appropriate water sources; and the two remaining technicians will unload the pallets. The techs will be available for other tasks when unpacking has been completed.

Use the buttons to compare the assignments you made with the team assignments chosen for this scenario.

Page.Name: Team Member
Page.TranscriptText:
Narrator: : While Maj Marks could split the team several different ways to accomplish these tasks based on team member strengths, for the purposes of this response he will proceed with assessment of the area where tent city is being constructed; the two BE NCOs, TSgt Hopper and SSgt Johnson, will work on identifying appropriate water sources; and the two remaining technicians will unload the pallets. The techs will be available for other tasks when unpacking has been completed.

Use the buttons to compare the assignments you made with the team assignments chosen for this scenario.

Page.Name: Team Lead
Page.TranscriptText: <U>Narrator:</U> The technicians have finished unpacking the pallets. The Public Health Tech has joined the IDMT in the clinic and the BE Tech, SrA Mukoda, has started assisting with other needed OESHA tasks. Your NCO team has been working on source water identification and assessment while you are continuing assessment of tent city. Select each team to review what assessment activities are being conducted.
Page.instruction: Select each team or item on the screen to continue assessing the situation.

The NCO team has been working on source water identification and assessment while the Team Lead is continuing assessment of tent city. Page.TranscriptText: <U>Narrator:</U> After a long, hot day of assessment, your team is ready to go to sleep for the night.

Page.Name: Team Lead
Page.TranscriptText: <U>Narrator:</U> After breakfast, you split your BE team members to accomplish needed tasks for the day. SrA Mukoda will continue working with soil assessment, while TSgt Hopper and SSgt Johnson, your BE NCOs, continue working with water analysis. You have a couple more air analysis tasks you need to complete. Select whether you'd like to complete your tasks or review the activities of your other team members first.
Page.instruction: Make your decision.

Page.Name: Team Member
Page.TranscriptText: <U>Narrator:</U> After breakfast, Maj Marks splits the BE team members to accomplish needed tasks for the day. SrA Mukoda will continue working with soil assessment, while TSgt Hopper and SSgt Johnson, the BE NCOs, continue working with water analysis. You are to assist Maj Marks with a couple more air analysis tasks that need to be completed. Select whether you’d like to complete your tasks or review the activities of the other team members first.
Page.instruction: Make your decision.

Page.TranscriptText:
Narrator: Based upon planning factors, the efficiency of the unit, and the quantity of water being supplied from the host nation, the single ROWPU available could produce approximately 8,333 gallons per day of treated water.

Using the 20 gallons per day allocation, the source water provided is not enough water to meet the demand.

The CE Commander concurred with your NCO team's recommendation to use bottled water for drinking.

At which three points should your NCOs establish routine sampling?
Page.instruction: Select all that apply, then click Done.

Page.TranscriptText:
PHO, Capt Hall (on radio): BE Team Lead this is the Public Health Officer, I'm headed over to the dining hall to investigate a spike in gastrointestinal complaints from patients we've been seeing at the clinic. Over.

BE Team Lead, Maj Marks (on radio): Copy. Have there been any other health issues in the two days we've been on-site? Over.

PHO, Capt Hall (on radio): Negative, just a few safety-related injuries. I'll inform you when I have more information. Out.
Page.Tab_1:
PHO, Capt Hall (on radio): BE Team Lead this is the Public Health Officer, I'm headed over to the dining hall to investigate a spike in gastrointestinal complaints from patients we've been seeing at the clinic. Over.

BE Team Lead, Maj Marks (on radio): Copy. Have there been any other health issues in the two days we've been on-site? Over.

PHO, Capt Hall (on radio): Negative, just a few safety-related injuries. I'll inform you when I have more information. Out.

Select the correct answer,
then click Done.

Page.instruction: Make your decision.

Page.CompentancyDescription: Interpret potable water sampling results.
Page.CompentancyTopic: Basic Site Assessment and Risk Communication Requirements
Page.STS_Line:
• 4.1.13 Sample result interpretation
  • 4.15.1.6 Field drinking water
Page.Training_Reference:
• AFMAN 48-138_IP, Sanitary Control and Surveillance of Field Water Supplies
  • BE Field Manual
Page.TranscriptText:
Lifeline: Lifeline, standing by.

BE Team Lead, Maj Marks: I need to be prepared to make a recommendation on the use of the ROWPU. What have you found?

BE NCO, TSgt Hopper: The results we have after analyzing the water from the system are:
  • Coliform - Negative
  • pH - 7.3
  • Total Organic Compounds of 500 milligrams per liter
  • Total Suspended Solids - 50 milligrams per liter
  • and Total Dissolved Solids of 250 milligrams per liter

    • Narrator: Based upon the results, does the ROWPU meet potable water guidelines?
Page.instruction:
Make your decision.
For assistance, click the Lifeline.

Page.Tab_1:
BE NCO, TSgt Hopper: I still have some concerns about the use of the ROWPU because of the KCN threat. It doesn't have high treatment efficiency for low molecular weight compounds such as alcohols and cyanide.

BE Team Lead, Maj Marks: SSgt Johnson, do you have any other thoughts?

BE NCO, SSgt Johnson: I think we go with the ROWPU, ensuring that an NBC filter is attached.

BE Team Lead, Maj Marks: Sounds good.

  • 4.5.1.5.1 Select appropriate occupational and environmental exposure limit (OEEL) (TLV, MCL, SPEGL, MEG, STEL, CELING, PEL, Excursion Limits, etc.)
  • 4.5.2.16 Interpret air sample results

Page.TranscriptText: <U>BE Team Lead, Maj Marks:</U> I found out that the last PM-10 measurements taken by the British military preventive medicine unit were 300 micrograms per cubic meter over a 24-hour sampling period. No additional information has been provided.
Page.instruction: Make your decision.

Page.CompentancyTopic: Basic Site Assessment and Risk Communication Requirements

  • OEHSA Documentation and Data Management Technical Guide
Page.TranscriptText:
PH Tech, SrA Pritt: Maj Marks? I noticed earlier that CE personnel are using paints containing Toluene in several construction projects around tent city.

I know that they're eager to please everybody and provide personnel with new facilities, but they're disregarding several standard health and safety practices such as evacuating other personnel while they work.

Aircraft Maintenance personnel that we evaluated earlier are going to retire to their new facility tonight after working a 12-hour shift conducting aircraft inspections.

Which of the following presents the greatest health risk?
Page.instruction:
Select the correct answer,
then click Done.

Page.Name: Team Member
Page.CompentancyDescription: Evaluate health risk and determine severity.

Page.TranscriptText:
PH Tech, SrA Pritt: I noticed earlier that CE personnel are using paints containing Toluene in several construction projects around tent city.

I know that they're eager to please everybody and provide personnel with new facilities, but they're disregarding several standard health and safety practices such as evacuating other personnel while they work.

Aircraft Maintenance personnel that we evaluated earlier are going to retire to their new facility tonight after working a 12-hour shift conducting aircraft inspections.

Which of the following presents the greatest health risk?
Page.instruction:
Select the correct answer,
then click Done.

Page.Tab_1:
PH Tech, SrA Pritt: Why do you consider the greatest health risk to be Aircraft Maintenance personnel sleeping in a facility that was recently painted? It doesn't seem like the exposure would be that high.

BE Team Lead, Maj Marks: The personnel were exposed to Methylene Chloride during the day and Toluene in the evening. While the exposure to each chemical may be harmless by itself, the combination of the two exposures could present a higher risk because both chemicals have similar target organs, which results in a cumulative exposure.

Page.TranscriptText: <U>SrA Mukoda:</U> My soil-gas measurements with the TVA-1000B were 10 ppm on the PID and 0 ppm on the FID.
Page.instruction:
Select the correct answer,
then click Done.

Page.Tab_1:
Commander, Col Potts (on radio): BE Team Lead this is the Commander. What's your position? Over.

BE Team Lead, Maj Marks (on radio): I'm with the PAM team in the command building. Over.

Commander, Col Potts (on radio): Copy. I'm on my way. I'd like to discuss your recommendations before you wrap-up for the day. Out.

BE Team Lead, Maj Marks (to PAM team, NOT on radio): Alright team, that'll do it. Go ahead and turn in, we'll pick up in the morning.

Page.TranscriptText:
BE Team Lead, Maj Marks: Col Potts, we found that Aircraft Maintenance personnel are exposed to chlorinated solvents while performing inspections on small aircraft parts in the maintenance hangar. They don't have their PPE with them.

Narrator: Which one of the following is NOT a recommendation that you should provide to Colonel Potts for consideration?
Page.instruction:
Select the correct answer,
then click Done.

Page.TranscriptText: <U>Commander, Col Potts:</U> Your team has done a thorough job. Get some rest.
Page.Tab_1: <U>Commander, Col Potts:</U> Your team has done a thorough job. Get some rest.

BE Expert: The major goals of this scenario were to understanding the OEHSA process and effectively and efficiently determine strategies relative to identifying and controlling hazards.

When performing a site assessment, conducting water vulnerability assessment is the highest priority. If team members are available, analysis of other areas can be conducted simultaneously.

Take a look at the listed objectives. Notice areas where you excelled and areas where you may want to brush up.

Print this feedback form for your reference. If you have further questions see your immediate supervisor for assistance.
Page.instruction: Print your feedback form for your records, then click Continue to return to the Menu.
Page.instruction_1: You've completed this scenario. Print this page, then proceed for feedback.
